explanations: This is basic form of a verb, as given in the dictionary
For group 1 verbs, the last sound of the ます-form is changed from the い-column to う-column
examples: 1) かきます → かく
1) To write
2) よみます → よむ
2) To read
3) とります → とる
3) To take
4) すいます → すう
4) To smoke
5) いそぎます → いそぐ
5) To hurry
6) あそびます → あそぶ
6) To play
7) まちます → まつ
7) To wait
8) はなします → はなす
8) To talk

explanations: For group 2 verbs, る is added to ます-form
examples: 1) たべます → たべる
1) To eat
2) みます → みる
2) To see

explanations: For group 3 ます-form verbs, if it ends in します，change the end to する
For group 3 ます-form verbs, if it ends in きます，change the end to くる
examples: 1) べんきょうします → べんきょうする
1) To study
2) きます → くる
2) To come

explanations: This expression is used to indicate that a person has the ability to do something
It can be also be used to indicate that some behavior is possible as a result of the situation
The object of できます is marked by が
examples: 1) ミラーさんは 日本語[にほんご]が できます。
1) Mr Miller can speak Japanese
2) 雪[ゆき]が たくさん 降[ふ]りましたから，ことしは スキーが できます。
2) A lot of snow has fallen, so we can ski this year

topic: Verb じしょ-form こと が できます
explanations: This expression is used to indicate that a person has the ability to do something
It can be also be used to indicate that some behavior is possible as a result of the situation
The object of できます is marked by が
We use the verb じしょ-form with こと to turn it into a noun phrase
examples: 1) ミラーさんは 漢字[かんじ]は 読む[よむ] ことが できます。
1) Mr Miller can read Kanji
2) カードで 払[はら]う ことが できます。
2) You can pay by card

topic: 私[わたし]の 趣[しゅ]味[み]は Noun です
explanations: This expression is used to indicate your hobby/interest
Using the verb じしょ-form with こと enables the interests to be described more specifically than just a noun
examples: 1) 私[わたし]の 趣[しゅ]味[み]は 音楽[おんがく]です。
1) I'm interested in music
2) 私[わたし]の 趣[しゅ]味[み]は 音楽[おんがく]を きく ことです。
2) I like listening to music

topic: Verb1 じしょ-form まえに，Verb2
explanations: This expression shows that Verb2 occurs before Verb1
[Note] Verb1 always takes the じしょ-form while Verb2 takes the tense of the sentence
examples: 1) 日本[にほん]へ 来[く]る 前[まえ]に，日本語[にほんご]を 勉強[べんきょう]しました。
1) Before I came to Japan, I studied Japanese
2) 寝[ね]る 前[まえ]に，本[ほん]を 読[よ]みます。
2) Before going to sleep, I read a book

explanations: This expression shows that Verb occurs before Noun
の is added after the noun
examples: 1) 食事[しょくじ]の まえに，手[て]を 洗[あら]います。
1) I wash my hands before eating

explanations: This expression shows how much time has passed after Verb occurs
[Note] that の is not added to a time period quantifier
examples: 1) 田中[たなか]さんは 1時間[じかん]前[まえ]に，出[で]かけました。
1) Tanaka went out an hour ago

explanations: When なかなか is followed by a negative expression, it means not easily or not as expected
examples: 1) 日本[にほん]へ なかなか 馬[うま]を 見[み]る ことが できません。
1) You don't see many horses in Japan

explanations: せび is used by speakers to intensify their expressions of hope
examples: 1) せび 北海道[ほっかいどう]へ いきたいです。
1) I really want to goto Hokkaido
2) せび 遊[あそ]びに来て ください
2) Please do come and visit me
